text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 13.4.2, Administration and Security.
IRM 13.4.2.1.2, added new acronyms and removed those no longer used in this IRM.
IRM 13.4.2.5.5, updated with current password rules based on Password Screen. SERP Feedback
IRM 13.4.2.8, clariﬁed example and added (4) and (5) to clarify when a case should not be deleted from the Taxpayer Advocate Management Information System (TAMIS).

IRM 13.4.2.8.1, clariﬁed only non-bargaining unit employees, speciﬁcally the Local Taxpayer Advocate (LTA), acting LTA, Centralized Case Intake (CCI) manager, or acting CCI manager can delete a case from TAMIS and updated the procedures for deleting cases.
IRM 13.4.2.8.1.1, moved Caution for clarity.
IRM 13.4.2.8.2, updated to current record retention procedures.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 13.4.2, Administration and Security, dated March 30, 2022. IRM Procedural Update (IPU) 22U0940 (issued 9/9/2022) has been incorporated into this IRM.
Taxpayer Advocate Service employees.
Acting Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support
Table of Contents
Policy Owner: The Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support (EDCA-ITS), who reports to the Deputy National Taxpayer Advocate
The following table contains a list of acronyms used throughout this IRM.

Acronym Deﬁnition AMS Accounts Management System BEARS Business Entitlement Access Request System CCI Centralized Case Intake CF Case File DBA Database Administrator DEDCA Deputy Executive Director Case Advocacy DNTA Deputy National Taxpayer Advocate EDCA-ITS Executive Director Case Advocacy, Intake and Technical Support ID Identiﬁcation Number

Acronym Deﬁnition IDRS Integrated Data Retrieval System Ind indicator IRM Internal Revenue Manual LTA Local Taxpayer Advocate NBU non-bargaining unit OAR Operations Assistance Request Org Organization OS Operations Support PID Personal Identiﬁcation Number SA System Administrator TAMIS Taxpayer Advocate Management Information System TAS Taxpayer Advocate Service TIN Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number
) TAS employees will use the following resources in conjunction with this • IRM
, TAS Guide for Managers; • IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures; and • TAMIS User Guide . (
) TAS managers are responsible for ensuring that all TAS cases are established on the TAMIS database and updated (i.e., closed, transferred etc.) accurately. See IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Management Information System (TAMIS), for more information. (
) TAS managers must ensure all personnel designated to access the TAMIS database are properly trained in order to use TAMIS effectively. Refer to
, TAMIS Training, for additional information regarding the training program and the TAMIS User Guide . (
) The National TAMIS Program Manager serves as the primary liaison between the TAS employees, the host site at the Enterprise Computing Center - Memphis, and the TAMIS developers. (

) The TAMIS developers, part of Application Development Internal Management, are responsible for developing the TAMIS application and other application related activities, such as implementing approved program changes, deﬁning the application’s workload volume, coordinating the testing, and repairing cation problems. (
) The Database Administrator (DBA) researches and resolves Oracle and database problems. The DBA maintains, monitors and backs up necessary
TAS employees will use the following resources in conjunction with this IRM:
The Database Administrator (DBA) researches and resolves Oracle and TAMIS database problems. The DBA maintains, monitors and backs up necessary
database ﬁles and table space as necessary. If required, the DBA forwards application-based problems and information to the TAMIS developers for lution. (
) Problems submitted to the Operation Support Customer Assistance Line at
or OS Ge
ervices at https://selfservice.web.irs.gov/webtier-
/ess.do are forwarded to the DBA . (
) TAMIS service hours (TAMIS real-time) are
hours per day, seven days a week. The DBA notiﬁes TAS of any scheduled or unscheduled downtime.
) Restricting Access to TAMIS Database (

) The System Administrator (SA) and DBA are the TAMIS security administrators and are responsible for processing all Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS) requests for access to the TAMIS Redesign (DCC Production Platform). They assign initial passwords, and maintain all necessary audit (

) The SA and DBA ensure that only authorized personnel are allowed access the TAMIS database for query, update, and report generation. Field personnel may not alter either the nationally developed programs or the database. (
) The SA or the DBA removes a user’s access to TAMIS when warranted. For example, employees who no longer require access to TAMIS due to reassign- ment, separating from TAS, or more than
days of inactivity.
) Maintaining the Integrity TAMIS (

) TAS managers are responsible for the integrity of the TAMIS database. TAMIS should be monitored to ensure the following: a. All cases are established accurately and timely on the TAMIS database and are properly coded. b. Accurate and timely case coding, including date ﬁelds. c. There is no unauthorized removal of cases. If cases are removed, refer to IRM

, Deleting Cases, for restrictions concerning removal of case from TAMIS. d. Monitor access to the system. When an employee no longer has a ﬁde business need to access TAMIS, submit a BEARS request selecting the option Remove Access to an Entitlement. See IRM
, Permanent Inactive Status. (

) The rules and regulations governing unauthorized access apply to all taxpayer systems of records including TAMIS. Individuals may only access TAMIS or individual cases for a bona ﬁde business purpose. Report generation or spe- cialized report writing using Business Objects Enterprise or Tableau should also be conducted on a “need to know” basis. (
) Use and sharing of statistics gathered from TAMIS is addressed in IRM TAS Balanced Performance Measurement System. (
) Access (
) This section addresses gaining access to the database and security responsi- bilities; for example, protecting your password and changing your password, compromised. Administration and Security
page
database ﬁles and table space as necessary. If required, the DBA forwards application-based problems and information to the TAMIS developers for reso- lution.
TAMIS service hours (TAMIS real-time) are 24 hours per day, seven days a week. The DBA notiﬁes TAS of any scheduled or unscheduled downtime.
TAS managers are responsible for the integrity of the TAMIS database. TAMIS should be monitored to ensure the following:

a. All cases are established accurately and timely on the TAMIS database and are properly coded. b. Accurate and timely case coding, including date ﬁelds. There is no unauthorized removal of cases. If cases are removed, refer to IRM

, Deleting Cases, for restrictions concerning removal of a case from TAMIS. d. Monitor access to the system. When an employee no longer has a bona ﬁde business need to access TAMIS, submit a BEARS request selecting the option Remove Access to an Entitlement. See IRM
, Permanent Inactive Status.
Permanent Inactive Status. (

) The rules and regulations governing unauthorized access apply to all taxpayer systems of records including TAMIS. Individuals may only access TAMIS or individual cases for a bona ﬁde business purpose. Report generation or spe- cialized report writing using Business Objects Enterprise or Tableau should also be conducted on a “need to know” basis. (
) Use and sharing of statistics gathered from TAMIS is addressed in IRM
, TAS Balanced Performance Measurement System. (
) This section addresses gaining access to the database and security responsi- bilities; for example, protecting your password and changing your password, if compromised.

) To access the TAMIS system, the TAS managers should: . a. Create a TAMIS Employee Screen ﬁrst. Refer to the TAMIS User Guide b. Then complete a BEARS request. Note: Completion of the TAMIS Employee Screen ﬁrst will avoid delays in process- ing BEARS requests. (
) Within the BEARS system, select
TAS Personnel (TAMIS Redesign (DCC Production Platform)) to obtain the appropriate access. (
) Management should review the BEARS request to ensure it is properly completed. In the Userid ﬁeld, enter the employee’s TAMIS Login Name . (

) Once the BEARS request is approved, you are provided with a temporary password to access TAMIS. You will be prompted to change the temporary password the ﬁrst time you log in. Note: Temporary passwords are only valid for
hours, if you don’t create a new password the same day, you may need to submit a BEARS password reset request. (
) You are responsible for maintaining the security of your TAMIS password. (
) Local Taxpayer Advocates (LTAs) and Centralized Case Intake (CCI) managers must ensure that all TAMIS users are trained in the proper use of the system. (
) Operations Support is responsible for TAMIS training coordination. (
) Course number

, Taxpayer Advocate Management Information System (TAMIS), can be conducted in a variety of methods. Ideally, the training should be taught using computers, allowing for individual hands-on practice. TAMIS can also be taught by combining group discussion with periods of hands-on practice at the student’s workstation. (
) The TAMIS course is designed to provide the mechanics of using the database. To access the TAMIS Training database, contact your local TAS Training or TAMIS coordinator for login instructions. (
) Separate training is available for the TAMIS report-writing software. (

) Director of TAS Systems Operations & Support will coordinate with EDCA-ITS to communicate TAMIS updates to all users when changes are implemented the TAMIS database. These communications will provide information covering the nature of the TAMIS changes and related user instructions. (

) Upon receipts of the communication, managers and employees should read the communication to determine the impact on their case actions. Managers and employees should contact their local TAMIS coordinator if the have questions concerning TAMIS functionality and send questions concerning TAMIS policy to the *TAS TAG Policy and Guidance mailbox.
TAS TAMIS Guide
You are responsible for maintaining the security of your TAMIS password.

Director of TAS Systems Operations & Support will coordinate with EDCA-ITS to communicate TAMIS updates to all users when changes are implemented in the TAMIS database. These communications will provide information covering the nature of the TAMIS changes and related user instructions.
) Protect your TAMIS password and do not reveal it to anyone. (
) Never use another person’s password. (
) Never leave your password in your desk or around your work area. (

) Lock the workstation screen, or sign off the system if you leave your worksta- tion for any length of time. Report any suspected compromise or abuse of the system to your local office security representative or management. (
) You should always change your password whenever you feel it has been com- promised. (
) If you have not logged into TAMIS for more than
days, you will be “locked out.” You must contact the Operation Support Customer Assistance Line at
, or complete a BEARS request selecting “Password Reset”. When contacting the help desk or completing the BEARS request, you must provide your TAMIS login. (
) If you have not logged into TAMIS within
days, your login will be removed from the system; and a new BEARS request must be completed to reinstate your access to TAMIS. See IRM
, Obtaining a Login and Password for TAMIS, for these procedures. (

) Your login and password systemically lock after three consecutive unsuccessful attempts at logging in using an incorrect password. To unlock your account, submit an account unlock request via BEARS: select Password Reset and notate in the Special Instructions “account unlock.” (
) Multiple login processes (i.e., a user being signed on more than once using same login and password and attempting to conduct two or more TAMIS sessions simultaneously) are not permitted. (
) Each user is only allowed one TAMIS user account. (
) “Idling” occurs when a user does not execute a keystroke or when the screen display does not change. (
) TAMIS users should sign off TAMIS if there is no need to take any TAMIS actions and/or if there is no need to have continual/uninterrupted access to database. (
) If you are idle for more than
minutes (
hours), you will be signed off. Any unsaved data will be lost. (
) You may change your password by selecting the Administration button from the TAMIS Main Menu, then the Password button on the Administration Menu. (
) Passwords are case sensitive and must: a. Be between
to

characters in length. b. Not be the same as the user name. c. Start with an alphabetic character. d. Have at least one lower-case alphabetic character. e. Have at least one upper-case alphabetic character. f. Have one to two numeric characters. g. Have one to two special characters. and Security
page Internal Revenue Manual
You may change your password by selecting the Administration button from the TAMIS Main Menu, then the Password button on the Administration Menu.
Be between
to

characters in length. Not be the same as the user name. Start with an alphabetic character. Have at least one lower-case alphabetic character. Have at least one upper-case alphabetic character. Have one to two numeric characters. Have one to two special characters.
Differ from the previous password by least three letters.
Special Characters Available for Use in Passwords
Symbol Symbol Description ! Exclamation Point - Hyphen = Equal Sign . Period ~ Tilde _ Underscore { } Left and Right Braces [ ] Left and Right Brackets : Colon
If your password has been compromised, change your password immediately.

Example: An employee in Org code 28 accepts a detail assignment as an acting group manager in Org code 25. To access the detailed-to office’s inventory and assign cases, the acting manager requires login rights to Org code 25.
) Login names and Employee ID # cannot be duplicated on another TAMIS Employee Screen. (

) Complete a BEARS request to request a new TAMIS login and password for the temporary site. On the BEARS request, Special Instructions ﬁeld, provide the new TAMIS Login Name and advise the system administrator that the existing TAMIS Login Name should be disabled (provide the existing Login Name ).
) Once assigned to the new office, employees will not be able to actively work cases assigned to the losing office Org code. The losing office must reassign all open inventory. (
) Update the Employee Screen as follows: a. The Employee Screen at the losing office Org code must be modiﬁed. The level
or
permission user at the losing Org Code must update Employee Screen, setting the Inactive Ind to Inactive. b. A new Employee Screen for the detailed-to Org code must be estab- lished. The level
or

permission user at the detailed-to Org code must add a new Employee Screen using the new temporary employee login with a new Employee ID # . The new ID number follows the ID number format DTLxx. Example: Employee ##-DTLxx is comprised of ## for the Detailed to Org code, DTL to represent the fact the employee is on detail, and xx would be numbers
, etc., following a sequence for new detail in employees. Example: Employee DRHADD
is on detail to Org Code
The employee’s Login Name on the detailed-to Org Code Employee Screen is DRHADD
, and, if the user is the ﬁrst detail-in employee, their Employee ID # is
-DTL
) The detailed in employee would be given the appropriate permissions, for example, case assignment privileges and the appropriate permission level. (

) Once the detail assignment is complete, and the employee returns to their home Org code, their access rights must be reestablished at their home Org code and the temporary detailed-to office must modify the Employee Screen follows: a. The temporary detailed-to Org code must reassign all open inventory. b. The detailed-to Org code must set the Inactive Ind to Inactive. c. The home Org code must update the Inactive Ind to Active on the original Employee Screen. (

) Upon completion of the temporary assignment, the employee must complete BEARS request. On the BEARS, Special Instructions ﬁeld, advise the system administrator to enable the original TAMIS Login Name (and include the login), requesting a new password, and advise that the temporary TAMIS Login Name should be disabled (and include that login). A new temporary password will provided for the original TAMIS Login Name. or (

When the Smart Card is issued, enter the Personal Identiﬁcation Number (PID) in the Employee Screen PID ﬁeld. (

If you have been assigned a new badge number ( Employee ID # ), due to a name change, etc., a new Employee Screen must be created.

complete a new BEARS request, to gain access, unless your name has changed as well, which requires access under a new Login Name . (

) If a new badge was issued and there is a new name: a. On the BEARS request, Special Instructions ﬁeld, provide the new Login Name and advise the system administrator that the existing Login Name should be disabled (provide the existing Login Name ). b. The level
or
permission user in the Org code must update the Employee Screen of the old/original Employee ID # or badge number permission level

c. Do not edit the Login Name on the old/original Employee Screen. d. Add a new Employee Screen with the new Employee ID # and Login Name , including assigning the appropriate permission level. e. Once open inventory is reassigned to the new Employee ID# , the Inactive Ind on the original Employee Screen must be set to Inactive. (

) If there is a new name, but a new badge was not issued: a. On the BEARS request, Special Instructions ﬁeld, provide the new Login Name and advise the SA that the existing TAMIS Login Name should be disabled (provide the existing Login Name ). b. The level
or

permission in the Org code user must update the Employee Screen of the old/original Login Name to permission level c. Do not edit the Login Name on the old/original Employee Screen. d. Add a new Employee Screen with the new Login name including assigning the appropriate permission level. e. Reassign all open inventories to the new Employee ID # . All closed cases will remain on the database under the original Employee ID # . f. Due to the requirement for a unique Employee ID # , the new Employee Screen displays a modiﬁed Employee ID # . ) Employee Permanently Reassigned Another TAS Office (
) If you have been permanently reassigned to another TAS office, you will need a new Login Name for the new organization code. Complete a BEARS request to gain access under the new Org code. (

) Request a new TAMIS login and password for the new site. On the BEARS request, Special Instructions ﬁeld, provide the new TAMIS Login Name and advise the system administrator that the existing TAMIS Login Name should be disabled (provide the existing Login Name ). (
) You may also receive a new badge number, depending on the new location.
You may also receive a new badge number, depending on the new location.
) Since you cannot have dual log in accounts or dual Employee ID #’s on TAMIS, the following procedures/steps are to be followed by a level
or
mission user in the losing office: a. The Employee Screen at the losing office Org code must be modiﬁed. The level
or
permission user must update the Employee Screen. b. Reassign open inventory. c. The Inactive Ind box must be updated to Inactive. d. The permission level must be changed to
e. Insert “employee reassigned” in the street address line. f. Update the local telephone number to the employee’s manager’s or retary’s telephone number. g. Do not modify the existing login ﬁeld. (
) The gaining office will create a new Employee Screen using the new Login Name . Input the new badge number ( Employee ID# ) and IDRS number, if new badge and IDRS number was issued. (

) If the employee is reassigned to a new location and retains the same badge number, the format for the TAMIS Employee ID # is ## -Nxxxx: where ## equals the Org Code, N represents new, and xxxx equals the last four digits the badge number or Smart Card PID. (
) If a user does not have a business need to access TAMIS, their Employee Screen must be updated. (
) The Employee Screen cannot be removed; instead a level
or
permission user in the Org code should edit the screen as follows: a. Update the permission level to
b. Update the local telephone number to the employee’s manager’s or retary’s telephone number. c. Update the Inactive Ind to Inactive. d. Do not modify the existing Login Name ﬁeld. (
) All open inventory must be reassigned. (
) The employee or employee’s manager must submit a BEARS request to remove the application. (
) A permission level is assigned to every employee who is listed on the Employee Screen. See IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Management formation System (TAMIS), for information on assigning TAMIS Permission Levels by position. (
) Depending on your permission level, you will be able to view data, add data, remove data. See IRM
, Making Deviations from a TAMIS Per- mission Level, for additional information. (
) Level
access has been established for four Headquarters employees. The level
users can update cases and Employee Screens for any organization code. Generally, the level
permission users only assist if the action cannot be input by level
users at the affected office. (
) Refer to the TAS Permission Levels list on the TAS TAMIS/IRM web page the following link: TAMIS Permission Levels Internal Revenue Manual

Level 5 permission users have limited ability to change codes or the list of values within TAMIS.
) Level
permission users have limited ability to change codes or the list of values within TAMIS.
) Deleting Cases (
) Only Permission Level
users within the same TAMIS Org code or a level
Super User can delete or remove a case from TAMIS. a. CCI employees retain the Org code on TAMIS of the LTA office in which they are located. b. CCI managers have Permission Level
(see IRM

, TAMIS Per- mission Levels). Therefore, CCI managers are responsible for reviewing and approving deleted case requests submitted by Intake Advocates reporting to the CCI manager before they delete the case. (

) The ability to delete or remove cases is an administrative tool which should exercised in limited situations. TAMIS case removal should be kept to a minimum. In general, there are only two situations that warrant a case removal: • If at the time of case creation, a case was added erroneously to TAMIS. Example: The taxpayer’s problem is already resolved by an Opera- tion’s actions, but TAS did not recognize it was resolved. • A duplicate case has been added to TAMIS. Example: The case is identical in the taxpayer’s entity to an existing case. If new inquiry has the same entity as the open case and the taxpayer is raising new issue(s) or tax account(s), the new issue(s) or tax account(s) should be added to the existing case.
If at the time of case creation, a case was added erroneously to TAMIS.
Example: The taxpayer’s problem is already resolved by an Opera- tion’s actions, but TAS did not recognize it was resolved.

Example: The case is identical in the taxpayer’s entity to an existing case. If new inquiry has the same entity as the open case and the taxpayer is raising new issue(s) or tax account(s), the new issue(s) or tax account(s) should be added to the existing case.
Reminder: When creating an e-

on Accounts Management System (AMS) to add a case to TAMIS, dialogue boxes will appear if a case involving the same Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN) is already on TAMIS. A similar dialogue box occurs when loading a case directly to TAMIS. Before continuing with the e-
or TAMIS records, the employee will review the existing TAMIS case(s) to determine if the issue is a duplicate or possible re-open. See IRM
, Inquiries on Open and Closed TAMIS Cases.

) TAMIS cases that have speciﬁc data imperfections or errors (e.g., incorrect dates, premature closure, erroneous reopen record, or erroneous data in a protected ﬁeld) should not be removed. Each TAS office should correct these data elements. If errors cannot be corrected by the local office level

permis- sion users, elevate the problem to your Area TAMIS Coordinator. If needed, the Area TAMIS Coordinator elevates the problem to Director of TAS Systems Op- erations & Support by submitting a Technology Request . (

) TAS employees make a case acceptance determination for AMS referrals from another IRS Operating Division or Function before creating a case on TAMIS. Once a case acceptance determination has been made, TAS will work the case. See IRM

, Referrals from IRS Operating Divisions/Functions. TAS employees will not make another case acceptance determination once the case has been loaded to TAMIS. Remember, the IRS has informed the taxpayer of TAS assistance, and this decision was conﬁrmed by a TAS
employee who worked the AMS referral and accepted the case. Do not delete cases once they have been established on TAMIS when you disagree with the case acceptance determination. (

) There are times when new information is presented after a case has been loaded to TAMIS, and the taxpayer or representative no longer requires assis- tance from TAS, or the taxpayer has received relief from the Operating Division or Function. These cases should not be deleted, instead they should be closed as a No Relief Code
, taxpayer withdraws relief request, or No Relief Code
, Operating Division or Function already provided relief. See IRM
, Withdrawal or Requested Closure of TAS Case, and IRM
, Relief Codes. Deleting (

) If a TAMIS case warrants removal, the following actions MUST be taken prior to removal. a. Forward a request for case deletion via secure email to the CCI manager, or LTA. The request should indicate the case ﬁle number to deleted with a detailed reason as to why the case needs to be deleted. Include the duplicate case ﬁle number when required. Note: To assist the CCI manager or LTA, consider using the following subject line: Case Deletion Request CF

) The LTA, officially designated acting LTA, CCI manager, or officially designated acting CCI manager will determine whether the case should be deleted. When the LTA or CCI manager determines the case will be deleted, they will: a. Document TAMIS, copy and paste the email request to delete the case into the TAMIS History to explain the reason for the removal. b. If the case to be removed is a duplicate of a case already on TAMIS, both cases must be documented before the duplicate is removed. Duplicate the History Screen to the original case. Example: CF#

Generate and print a hardcopy and electronic copy of Form
H, for the case to be removed. Print the Form
H to a .pdf format and name the document with the case number and deletion date, e.g.,
-mm-dd- yyyy.pdf. CCI Managers will promptly provide the hardcopy Form
H to the LTA in the office in which they are located for records retention purposes. Send the electronic copy of Form
H via secure email to TAS.TAMIS.Case.Deletions@irs.gov on the same day it is removed from TAMIS. When printing the Form

Only permission level 4 users, or above can delete/remove a case.
) Only permission level
users, or above can delete/remove a case. Caution: Once you delete the record, the deletion cannot be reversed. (
) Cases are deleted/removed from the Taxpayer Screen. (
) To delete the case, query the case in the Case File # ﬁeld. (
) Select Record followed by Remove on the menu bar or Delete Record from the icon bar. Note: Reopen cases cannot be removed after the Initial Actions and/or Closing Actions Screens are saved. (
) The following conﬁrmation displays: • Are you sure you want to delete this case? Select Yes or No. (
) The LTA and CCI manager are the designated NBU officials allowed to remove cases. The LTA and CCI manager should officially designate a back-up NBU employee with TAMIS permission level
to this task when absent from the office for more than seven calendar days. (
) The LTA retains the hard copy case removal records, including those sent to the LTA from co-located CCI managers. See IRM
, Procedures for Deleting a TAMIS Case. (
) Each office should keep a complete hardcopy Form
H for every case it removed during the current and prior ﬁscal years. These records may be requested for validation purposes during an Operational Review. See IRM
, Operational Reviews. (
) Each office will also send an electronic copy of the Form
H via secure email to TAS.TAMIS.Case.Deletions@irs.gov. a. Print the Form
H to a .pdf format and name the document with the case number and deletion date, e.g.,
-mm-dd-yyyy.pdf. (
) The hardcopy version should be securely stored to prevent any unauthorized browsing or disclosure. Select a secure cabinet location to maintain the printed Forms
H. Access should be limited to the LTA, NBU secretary, and the employee with TAMIS permission level
designated as the responsible person for case deletions and record retention when the LTA is out of the office for more than seven calendar days. (
) The retention period for a deleted case record is two years from the end of ﬁscal year of case removal. At the end of the retention period these reports should be destroyed. See Document
, Records and Information Manage- ment Records Control Schedules.

Print the Form 911H to a .pdf format and name the document with the case number and deletion date, e.g., 1234567-mm-dd-yyyy.pdf.
) The LTA is required to review the office’s case removal report to ensure that hardcopy Form
H exists for every listed case removal, to determine the propriateness of the case removal. Report and (
) Reports must be generated and retained to track the removal of cases from the TAMIS database. (
) On a semi-monthly basis each office must generate and print a case removal report that lists all cases removed for that time period. (
) One report must be run in deletion order to list cases removed from the
st through the
th day of the month. The other report must be run to list cases removed from the
th to the last day of the month. (
) The reports should be run within
days after the end of the semi-monthly period. (
) The report should be associated with the hardcopy Forms
H for the case listed on the report. These should be retained for the retention period described in IRM
, Case Removal Record Retention. (
) Each office must designate an NBU employee (DEDCA, Director, LTA, or designee) to review the office’s case removal report to ensure that a hardcopy Form
H exists for every listed case removal, to determine the appropriate- ness of the case removal. (
) Any knowingly inappropriate or unaccounted for case removal may constitute an unauthorized alteration of taxpayer data. (
) Director of TAS Systems Operations & Support generates and retains consoli- dated national case removal reports. (

) Area Offices and the Director CCI should generate and retain consolidated case removal reports for all offices within their jurisdiction. It is recommended that case removal review and analysis be part of a local office’s operational review. See IRM
, Operational Reviews. Note: The Director CCI (or designee) will have access to the electronic versions the Form
-H in order to conduct these reviews. (

) Area Offices and the Director CCI will take the following actions each month: a. Extract the deleted case information on the ﬁrst day of each month for the prior month for each office within the Area and CCI. b. Compare for the electronic version of the Form
-H with deleted records on the extraction list to verify the deleted record was preserved as required by IRM
c. The Area office and Director CCI will review the deleted record(s) by

th of each month for the prior month to ensure procedures were followed. d. If procedures were not followed, the Area Office and Director CCI will promptly alert any office to take the required corrective action. and Security

Operations Requests (
) Only Permission Level
users within the same TAMIS Org code or a level
Super User can delete an Operations Assistance Request (OAR) from TAMIS. (
) The ability to delete or remove OARs is an administrative tool which should exercised in limited situations. TAMIS OAR removal should be kept to a minimum. See IRM

, Advocating with Operations Assistance Requests (OARs). In general, OARs should only be removed from TAMIS when the OAR was: a. Created in error or prematurely; and b. Created on TAMIS and never issued.
Only Permission Level 4 users within the same TAMIS Org code or a level 5 Super User can delete an Operations Assistance Request (OAR) from TAMIS.
Caution: Once you delete the OAR, the deletion cannot be reversed.

) The LTA or officially designated acting LTA will determine whether the OAR should be deleted. When the LTA determines the OAR will be deleted, they will document TAMIS explaining the reason for the removal of the OAR. To delete the OAR:

the OAR: a. Select the OAR button and scroll to the OAR to be removed. b. Select Record and Remove from the menu bar or Delete Record from the icon bar. c. ) The ability to delete or remove a Reopen Record an administrative tool which should be exercised in limited situations. TAMIS Reopen Record removal should be rare. See IRM

, Reopen Procedures. In general, Reopen Records should only be removed from TAMIS when: a. The customer has not provided the previously requested information the case was reopened prematurely; b. There are no Service errors that warranted the case reopening; or c. The case was reopened in error or was the incorrect case number. (

) Reopen Records are removed from the case on the Reopen Screen. Caution: If you are not on the Reopen Screen, you will delete the Reopen Record and the original case from TAMIS . This action cannot be reversed. (

) The LTA or officially designated acting LTA will determine whether the Reopen Screen should be deleted.
